title: Fortnite black hole leaves grieving dad's charity livestream for dead son ruined
text:

A grieving dad has told how his plans to run a 24 hour Fortnite marathon in honour of his late son have been ruined after the game was 'sucked into a black hole'.

Arron Anderson, 28, had hoped to livestream himself playing the game tomorrow night in order to raise thousands of pounds for the children’s hospice that treated his son.

Tragic Harvey Anderson, who had cerebral palsy, died when he was just six years old earlier this year after developing a chest infection.

Since then, his devastated father has helped raise money for Helen & Douglas House hospice, in Oxford, and has set up a GoFundMe .

But his latest attempt at fundraising may not go ahead after developers Epic Games took the game offline.

(Image: Arron Anderson)

(Image: Epic Games)

He said: “I'm disappointed, it has come at the worst time really.

"Nobody expected this to happen and right before my fundraiser, it's made me wonder where I go from here.

"We're just hoping it returns soon.

"The hospice was a massive support for the whole family.

“Harvey spent a lot of time there, they were totally invaluable, so now it’s time to give back."

Arron was one of many that tuned in last night expecting to see the unveiling of Season 11 of the hit game.

But instead he watched everything in the game get sucked into a black hole.

Now Epic, the developer behind Fortnite, has also deleted all tweets from the Fortnite Twitter page, leaving only the live stream for fans to watch and Arron cannot play or even access the game which he had hoped would help raise £2,000 for the hospice.

(Image: Epic Games)

(Image: Epic Games)

He said: "I chose Fortnite because it's the go to game to get people to watch so I knew it would help generate money.

"Earlier in the year I raised £285 so I had hoped to raise a couple of thousand this time.

"The charity isn't government funded so they run off donations from the public.

"So the more we can give back, more families will be better off.

"But now we've been left in the dark."

Arron, of Banbury, Oxfordshire, said Harvey was in and out of hospital throughout his life.

He added: "From day one, the charity was there and offering us places to go and stay to have a break.

(Image: Epic Games)

"They were invaluable and the facilities were amazing.

"Harvey was one of the happiest children, he never cried, even when he was going through all these issues.

description: EXCLUSIVE: Dad Arron Anderson had hoped to raise thousands for the charity that looked after his terminally ill son, Harvey, before his death earlier this year
